Chapter 8, section 4 on the four unobstructed analytical knowledges and the concentration of liberation, having explained the immeasurables, next explains the liberations.
Verse:
There are eight kinds of liberation, the first three have the nature of non-greed,
Two are one definite concentration, the four formless concentrations are wholesome.
The liberation of the cessation of sensation and conceptualization arises from the subtle and very subtle [concentrations],
Due to the pure mind of one's own stage and the undefiled [concentration] below, one emerges.
The three objects are visible in the desire realm, the four objects are the class of the path,
The suffering, accumulation, and cessation of one's own and higher stages, the cessation of discrimination and non-discrimination, and space.ğŸ”½Discussion:
Herein,

There are eight liberations: the first is the liberation of the internal perception of form and the external perception of form; the second is the liberation of the internal non-perception of form and the external perception of form; the third is the liberation of the body's realization and perfect abiding in the pure liberation; the next four are the four formless concentrations as the next four liberations; and the perception-sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is the eighth liberation.
Among the eight, the first three have non-greed as their nature, because they are close to the antidote of greed.
However, in the sutras it is said:
The perceiver of conceptualization is because conceptualization increases, just as the recollection of past lives removes the conceptualization of form.
Among the three, the first two are the transformation of the characteristics of impurity, because they take on the characteristics of various activities such as blue, rotting, etc.
The third liberation is the transformation of the characteristics of purity, because it transforms into the characteristics of pure radiance.
When the three are combined with their auxiliaries, they all have the nature of the five aggregates.
The first two liberations are both based on the first two meditations, because they can counteract the greed for visible form in the desire realm and the first meditation.
The first two comprehensively include the preliminary stages and the intermediate state, because they can arise in the five stages.

The desire realm and the first trance state have craving for visible form, because they are attracted by the body of visual consciousness. In order to be liberated from them, the first two pure liberations are established in the first two trance states.

In the second and third trance states, there is no visual consciousness, and there is also no craving for visible form that is attracted by it. Therefore the first two pure liberations do not exist in the third and fourth trance states.

Although the two roots of good similar to the first two liberations may exist in the desire realm, they are mixed with the craving of the desire realm, and therefore the name of the two liberations is not established.

Although they may exist in the third and fourth trance states, they are far removed from their objects of abandonment and are weak in power, and they are also subdued by pleasure and purity. Therefore they are not given the name of the third liberation.
It is established on the basis of the fourth trance state, because the mind is clear and pure, free from the eight faults.
The fourth trance state and its preliminary concentration are given the name of the fourth trance state.

Although similar wholesome roots exist in the lower stages, they are not called liberations because they are not dominant. Because they are mixed with the desire realm's desire and greed, because the first two concentrations are suppressed by impurity, because the third concentration is deluded by bliss, and because they are all disturbed by the eight calamities.
The next four liberations are, in their order, by nature the wholesome of the four formless concentrations. They are neither indeterminate nor defiled, because they are not liberations.
They are also not scattered wholesome [roots], because their nature is weak.
Those scattered wholesome [roots] are like the mind at the end of life.
Some say that at other times there are also scattered wholesome [roots], but only innate wholesome [roots] are without hearing and thinking.

The nine uninterrupted paths and eight liberation paths of the preliminary stages are also not liberations, because they do not turn their backs on the lower stages, because they are mixed with the paths of the lower stages,
and because they have not completely freed themselves from the defilements of the lower stages. A scripture says that they transcend the lower stages.
Some say that the liberation paths of the preliminary stages are also called liberations, because they turn their backs on the lower stages.
However, in other places it is said that only the fundamental samÄdhi is the support of the samÄdhi of cessation, because in the preliminary concentrations there is not complete liberation.

The eighth liberation is the samÄdhi of cessation. It is produced by turning away from and despising feeling and conceptualization, or it is produced by turning away from and despising all objects of sense and understanding.
However, the elder DharmatrÄta says,
The state of the continuity of sentient beings is called the samÄdhi of cessation.
This is also unreasonable, because we have already discussed this at length. The samÄdhi of cessation must have a real substance.
Also, it cannot be said that this samÄdhi has mind, because we have never seen mind without feeling, conceptualization, and volition. It is impossible to go beyond the path.

It is said that in this samÄdhi, feeling, conceptualization, etc., are extinguished, and it is peaceful and happy. The arhat, etc., have such a superior liberation. If it has no substance, how can the continuity of mind and its activities be said to be peaceful and happy?
How can the superior liberation of the arhat, etc., be imagined?
There is a kind of mind that has no object and evolves apart from the characteristics of activity.
If there is an object, there must be contact. If you admit that there is contact, how can there be no feeling as a result?
What prevents feeling, etc., from arising?
Therefore there is no mental activity in the samÄdhi of cessation.
Those who are confused about the correct principles of the scriptures and who merely skim the texts are unable to understand the profound purport of the holy teachings.

The statement that consciousness is not eternally extinguished and does not leave the body is like the case where a disease is not yet permanently cured, and a temporary remission is still called having the disease.

This samÄdhi appears after the mind of the second and third formless realms, and the mind of the peak of existence is called subtle, and this is even more subtle, and is therefore called very subtle. Next, a mind like this enters the samÄdhi of cessation.

That is, the mind of the peak of existence has three grades, namely, the mind of conceptualization, the subtle mind, and the very subtle mind, because of the distinction of superior, middling, and inferior grades.
The samÄdhi of cessation appears only after the inferior grade, and therefore after the very subtle mind one enters the samÄdhi of cessation.

When one emerges from the samÄdhi of cessation, one either produces a pure thought of the peak of existence or one produces a thought of the sphere of nothingness that is pure and uncontaminated. The thought that enters this samÄdhi is only contaminated, but one emerges from it through a contaminated or an uncontaminated thought.

Among the eight liberations, the first three only take the form base of the desire realm as their object. There is a difference in that two take the impure as their object and one takes the pure as its object.
Since there is also a pure realm among all forms, when one generally views them as impure, why are they not categorized as perversions?
It is like the case of taking impermanent dharmas as a self, which is a perversion.

That is, since there is also suffering mixed in among the conditioned dharmas, taking them as only pleasure is a perversion. The third liberation, which takes the pure as its object, is also a perversion.
This is not a mistake, because it is accepted.
That is, it is also accepted that this is a perverted thought.
If this is so, how is it not of the nature of non-good?
It is the result obtained by the separation from the passions.
Since it does not accord with reality, how can it be able to oppose the passions?
Because the attention that produces it is distant.

For example, one who is not yet free from desire, when contemplating the pure characteristics of the impure, can give rise to craving. This is not seeing the pure characteristics in the pure, because it is not a mistaken view and can be categorized as wholesome.

In the same way, one who is free from desire, when contemplating the impurity of the pure and the impure, can become detached from craving. This is not seeing the impure characteristics in the pure, because it is a mistaken view and is categorized as unwholesome.
One should also explain the case of seeing the impure as pure in the same way.
Or this is not called mistaken contemplation. All impure dharmas are generally of two kinds: first, the substance itself; second, that which is mixed with them.
Because pure dharmas are mixed with the impure, they are also called impure. This is universally recognized in the world, and therefore this contemplation is not called mistaken.
The impure mixed with the pure should be the same.

However, when a practitioner of contemplation first cultivates contemplation, he does not take the aspect of impurity in the pure realm, but only takes the aspect of impurity in the impure realm, causing the mind to turn to the aspect of extreme disgust and opposition. Later, gradually increasing and expanding the aspect of opposition, he universally arouses a mind of disgust in the objects of the form realm in the desire realm and does not give rise to defiled craving.
If in a pure realm, a form aggregate in the form realm, one's resolve would be unable to take the aspect of impurity.

Since one's resolve is only able to take the aspect of impurity in the form aggregates in the desire realm, one should know that in the form aggregates in the desire realm there definitely also exists the nature of the impure realm.
Since it is like taking impurity and forming the understanding of impurity, how can it be said to be the nature of error?
The third, taking purity, should be understood as an example of this.
Since this turns to the object as it really is, how is it said to be the attention of resolve?
Because this arises toward the object by the power of resolve, it is said to be the attention of resolve.
For this reason it is called liberation, because the meanings of â€œsuperior resolveâ€ and â€œliberationâ€ are similar.
Or, in regard to a small object, by the power of superior resolve one gradually increases it and observes it, which is called attention accompanied by superior resolve.
That is, one gradually increases and observes a small pure object, and because of this one produces an immeasurable amount of defiled craving.
When this craving is produced, the mind is constrained by the object and does not function freely.
One gradually increases and observes a small impure object, and the opposite occurs, and one increases the roots of good.

It is like observing a pleasant feeling as having the nature of the suffering of change, because it is mixed with the characteristics of suffering. Observing it as suffering subdues the passions and is not called a perversion.
In the same way, the pure realm is mixed with the impure, and it is possible to observe it as impure, and this is not called a perversion.
It is also like this in the case of the pure liberation that is able to distance itself from craving.
It should be understood that when the observation is not yet complete, it is only called attention accompanied by superior resolve.
At the time of completion, it is also called true attention because it is the result of separation from passions and because it attracts the holy path.
The first three objects have been discussed in this way.

The next four deliverances each take as their objects the truths of suffering, cause, and cessation of their own stage and higher stages, the path of the class of subsequent knowledge of all stages, their non-determined cessation, and space.
The formless deliverances do not take lower stages as objects because they turn their backs on lower stages.

The aspects of the truths of suffering and cause of lower stages are different. The first two are impure, the third is pure only, and both are not the sixteen. The aspects of the formless deliverances are the sixteen because they include fundamental samÄdhis.

Or they are not associated with the applications of mindfulness. The first three deliverances are associated with the application of mindfulness of the body, and the next four deliverances are associated with the four applications of mindfulness.

As for the knowledges with which they are associated, the first three and the seventh are associated only with conventional knowledge, and the fourth, fifth, sixth, and eighth are associated with eight knowledges.
As for the associated faculties, the first two deliverances are associated with joy and indifference, the next five deliverances are only associated with indifference.
As for the distinction of time periods, all are common to the three time periods.

As for the distinction of objects in time, the first three deliverances, which are already arisen and can be arisen, each take their own time period as object, and those that are not yet arisen take the three time periods as objects.
The next four deliverances take the three time periods and non-time periods as objects.
As for the distinction of moral species, all are only of the nature of good.
As for the distinction of objects in moral species, the first three deliverances take the three moral species as objects, and the next four deliverances take good and indeterminate as objects.
As for the distinction of learners, etc., the first three and the last two are only neither learner nor post-learner, and the middle three deliverances are common to all three kinds.
As for the objects of learners, etc., the first three deliverances only take neither learner nor post-learner as objects, and the four take the three kinds as objects.

As for the distinction of being eliminated by seeing, etc., the first three and the last two are only eliminated by cultivation, and the middle three are eliminated by both [seeing and cultivation], and the rest are not eliminated.
As for the objects eliminated by seeing, etc., the first three take those eliminated by cultivation as objects, and the next four deliverances each take the three kinds as objects.

As for the objects of these meditations, the first two take as objects the bodies of self and others, the next two take as objects the bodies of others, and the last four take as objects all three kinds of bodies.
As for the differences in attainment, the eighth and third are only attained for the first time, while the other six are of two kinds.
The two kinds are the internal and external of the noble ones and ordinary beings, and ordinary beings only attain them for the first time.
What meaning is revealed by the sutra statement, One with form sees forms?
One who has not yet eliminated form cannot truly understand the profound meaning of this sutra. However, the ancient sages transmitted and explained it as follows:
The meaning of having form is that one has not yet subdued and eliminated the conceptualization of internal form.
How do we know this?
Because it is explained differently in the second liberation.
That is to say, in the second liberation, it says:
Internally without conceptualization of form, one sees external forms.
Therefore, we know that in the first liberation, one has not yet eliminated the conceptualization of internal form.
For this reason, the author establishes the first liberation as the liberation of having internal conceptualization of form, seeing external forms.
That is, the contemplator, although already free from craving for sexual desire, in order to make his mind firm, again contemplates external forms with the aspect of impurity.
Because he frequently observes external forms, he also produces a thought of disgust toward internal forms.
It is like one who delights in purity, who, having a dogâ€™s corpse hung around his neck, is extremely ashamed and disgusted.
In this way, having contemplated the impure characteristics of external forms, he then sees that his own body is also impure.

Because his mind is pure, he sees that the thirty-six substances in his body are filled with impurity, which he contemplates as being like various colored objects in a box. This is called the stage of perfect accomplishment of the first liberation.
What dharma is liberated in this stage of perfect accomplishment?

It means that the mind is displeased with form, turns away from it, reviles it, despises it, and stops craving for it. It is liberated from craving for sexual desire, because it is by nature non-greed.
If it is said that it should be wisdom because it is said to be contemplation, that is not necessarily so, because it is the proximate antidote to craving for sexual desire.
If its substance were discernment, it would be close to the antidote of delusion;
since it is close to the antidote of craving, it is by nature noncraving.
The practitioner of contemplation gradually eliminates the internal conception of form at a later time.

That is, he imagines that his own life ends, and his corpse is carried to a place where corpses are discarded, where various birds and beasts struggle to eat it, and in an instant the body is gone, and he only sees birds and beasts.
Or in this place, he imagines that the body is burned by fire, and even the remaining ashes are blown away by the wind, and in an instant the body is gone, and he only sees empty space.
Or he imagines that his own body is like butter or salt, etc., melted by fire or water, etc., and finally the body is gone and he only sees fire, etc.
This is called the liberation of the internal absence of conception of form and the observation of external form.
Because the power of this resolve eliminates the conception of form, although it arises in dependence on the body, one does not see the body.
Having already eliminated the internal conception of form, the continuity of mind evolves without any separate activity. The superior lightness and bliss manifest spontaneously.

In this stage, one repeatedly cultivates the aspect of aversion to the object of the form realm. This is called the second liberation being perfected, just like the first liberation and the desire realm greed.

Although in the past one has already cultivated the thought of impurity and attained liberation from the greed of the form realm, the self-love that has lasted since beginningless time is difficult to dispel. If one contemplates that the body exists, one is still afraid of falling back into birth. Therefore, one later again cultivates the internal formless thought, despising the form contemplation and purifying it even more than before.

At that time, the practitioner, relying on the first dhyÄna, deeply tastes and becomes attached to these two contemplations. In order to make them further progress, he enters the second dhyÄna and again cultivates the two liberations, again cultivating the two dharmas in sequence as before.
Why can the despised form thought in this case be said to be associated with the feeling of joy?
The power of the stage makes it so, just like the cognition of suffering and its accumulation.
Or, because one sees the wholesome roots that one has cultivated reaching perfection, one should give rise to joy.
Having already attained liberation from the perception of form, although one still engages in the contemplation of disgust, it does not obstruct joy.

Next, one further enters the third meditative absorption. Because one is deluded by wonderful bliss, the mind becomes extravagant. Because of this, one is unable to cultivate the various liberations, but only gives rise to wholesome roots similar to liberation.
In this meditative absorption, the power of the stage is such that the contemplation of disgust and delight are both unable to succeed.

From this, one further cultivates the fourth meditative absorption. Because equanimity increases, the mind gradually becomes clear and pure. The various impure perceptions no longer increase, and therefore they are not called the first two liberations, but can only be called wholesome roots similar to liberation.

Because the yogin has long been contemplating impurity, he is disgusted and his mind becomes depressed. In order to stimulate it and cause it to produce joy for a while, or in order to temporarily relieve the fatigue of long cultivation, or in order to examine himself and see if he is capable of the contemplation of impurity, he again relies on the fourth trance state and, with regard to form in the desire realm, produces the resolve of purity. First he grasps the pure characteristics of precious garments, flowers, etc., and by the power of resolve he gradually expands his contemplation, pervading all objects and making them the characteristics of purity.
As a scripture says:
Later, he should grasp a few pure characteristics and generally contemplate all forms.
Although he stimulates the mind in this way, he is not agitated. Although he contemplates pure characteristics, he does not give rise to craving.

Knowing that the power of the wholesome roots has increased, he next again briefly gathers his mind on an object and, observing purity, abides in one object of observation. This stage is called the fulfillment of the liberation of purity, because he is able to completely abandon the thought of impurity.

This pure liberation is also like the second liberation, which contemplates external forms while internally devoid of conceptual thoughts of form. However, there are differences, namely, in the stage of support and the aspects of practice that are eliminated. Why is it only said that internally one is devoid of conceptual thoughts of form and eliminates conceptual thoughts of form internally, and not externally?
Because when one attains the first concentration, external conceptual thoughts have already been eliminated.

That is to say, when one attains the first concentration, external conceptual thoughts of form have already been eliminated. In the fourth concentration, there is no need to eliminate them again. This is because the meritorious dharmas are attained gradually.
Moreover, external conceptual thoughts of form are easily eliminated, and therefore when they are eliminated, liberation is not yet established.
Or, the thought of external form is eliminated in the sphere of empty space, and therefore the verse only says that internal form is eliminated.

If it is said that this phrase only denies the thought of form, then it is useless, because the meaning of â€œseeing external form but no internal formâ€ has already been established.

It is the sphere of empty space.
If it does not operate with the aspect of impurity, how can it be called the second liberation?
This is not a fault, because it is the preparatory stage of that.
That is to say, the phrase â€œno thought of internal formâ€ in this passage is the name of the second preparatory stage. The second liberation is called liberation for many reasons.

These liberations are based on the bodies of men and women, and both ordinary and saintly persons can cultivate and produce them.

Even though this samÄdhi is categorized as being of the summit of existence, it is like the dharmas of the higher stages and is obtained only by transcending the other stages.

For example, one enters the fundamental stage of infinite space only by transcending all craving for the fourth trance state, and one enters the fundamental stage of neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization only by transcending all craving for the stage of nothingness.
In the same way, one can enter the samÄdhi of cessation only by transcending all craving for the summit of existence.

That is, whether or not the craving of the summit of existence is eliminated, one must totally subdue it in order to enter this samÄdhi. Therefore, even though it is of that stage, it is said to transcend it.

Or, all those still in training who have already eliminated the propensities of the realm of form are called transcendents, because they have eliminated the propensities that are eliminated by the path of insight.
Or, the state of the peak of existence is of two kinds, because there is a distinction of states with mind and without mind. They are called transcendents because they transcend the state with mind.
Or, there is no error in saying that they transcend as is appropriate.
Only the third, the eight liberations, are called those who are physically identified, because they are mentioned as the two extremes and illustrate the rest.

In the liberations of form, purity is the extreme, and in the formless realm, cessation is the extreme. Or, it is because each is at the extreme of a realm. Or, it is only because these two are obtained only by those of the two vehicles, because they are not previously obtained, because they are obtained through great effort, and because they eliminate the great elements, form, mind, mental activities, and dharmas.

There is an interpretation that the third, the liberations, first takes the characteristic of purity through the power of resolve regarding the body and form, and later gradually eliminates them. Liberation is perfected and has the body as its object, and this is the ultimate.
Therefore, only this is called those who are physically identified.
